name: Snake Plant
tips: Water sparingly and avoid getting leaves wet to prevent rot. Prefers indirect light.
fact: Snake plants are also known as 'mother-in-law's tongue' because of their sharp, pointed leaves.

name: ZZ Plant
tips: Allow soil to dry out completely between watering. Can tolerate low light but prefers bright, indirect light.
fact: ZZ plants are native to eastern Africa and were first discovered by Western botanists in 1829.

name: Monstera
tips: Prefers bright, indirect light. Allow soil to dry out slightly between watering.
fact: Monstera plants are native to the tropical rainforests of Central and South America. They can grow up to 60 feet tall in their natural habitat!

name: Spider Plant
tips: Prefers bright, indirect light and moist soil. Propagates easily by planting 'spiderettes' in soil.
fact: Spider plants were popularized in the 1970s for their easy care and air-purifying qualities. They are also safe for pets!

name: Aloe vera
tips: Keep the plant in well-draining soil and water only when the top inch of soil is dry.Aloe vera can also be used as a natural skin moisturizer.
facts: Aloe vera is a succulent plant species that is found in many parts of the world and hasbeen used for medicinal purposes for centuries.

name: Basil
tips: Basil prefers well-drained soil and plenty of sunshine. Pinch off any flowers that appearto keep the plant from going to seed too quickly.
facts: Basil is a member of the mint family and is native to tropical regions of central Africaand Southeast Asia.

name: Spider Plant
tips: Spider plants prefer well-drained soil and bright, indirect sunlight. They can be propagated easily by planting the babies that grow on the ends of their stems.
facts: Spider plants are known for their long, thin leaves that resemble spider legs. They are native to tropical and southern Africa.

name: Mint
tips: Mint prefers moist, well-drained soil and partial shade. Keep the plant pruned to prevent it from taking over your garden.
facts: Mint is a fast-growing herb that is native to Europe and Asia. It has been used for culinary and medicinal purposes for thousands of years.
